Title.evidence: Infrared Thermography for Predicting Supraclavicular Brachial Plexus Block Failure: A Prospective Observational Study

Participants.evidence: included 80 adult patients undergoing upper-limb surgery under supraclavicular brachial plexus block. Eligibility criteria included adults aged 18–65 years, excluding those with wound or inflammation at the examination site, peripheral vascular disease, or peripheral neuropathy.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the accuracy of infrared thermography in predicting failed segmental supraclavicular brachial plexus block.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the ability of temperature change to predict failed block, defined as absence of complete sensory loss 30 minutes after block completion.

Number_Randomised.evidence: included 80 adult patients undergoing upper-limb surgery under supraclavicular brachial plexus block. Conducted at Cairo University Hospital from February 2021 to March 2022

Result_Outcome.evidence: The AUC (95% CI) for temperature change at 5 minutes to predict failed ulnar, median, and radial nerve block was 0.79 (0.68–0.87), 0.77 (0.67–0.86), and 0.79 (0.69–0.88), respectively. AUC values increased to 0.98 (0.92–1.00), 0.97 (0.90–0.99), and 0.96 (0.89–0.99) at 15 minutes, with a negative predictive value of 100%.
